explanation: The MacBook Pro 14-inch with M4 (512GB) is a high-end laptop primarily composed of aluminum (for the chassis), various plastics, glass (for the screen), and electronic components including silicon chips, batteries, and circuit boards. Typical material composition estimates for laptops are approximately 30% aluminum, 20% plastics, 15% glass, 25% electronic components (including silicon and metals like copper, gold, and rare earths), and 10% battery materials. The weight of a 14-inch MacBook Pro is around 1.6 kg. Using common emission factors: aluminum production emits about 12 kg CO2e per kg, plastics about 6 kg CO2e per kg, glass about 1.5 kg CO2e per kg, electronic components about 50 kg CO2e per kg (due to complex manufacturing and rare materials), and lithium-ion batteries about 150 kg CO2e per kg. Calculating weighted emissions: (0.48 kg Al * 12) + (0.32 kg plastics * 6) + (0.24 kg glass * 1.5) + (0.4 kg electronics * 50) + (0.16 kg battery * 150) = 5.76 + 1.92 + 0.36 + 20 + 24 = 52.04 kg CO2e. However, this only accounts for raw material production. Including manufacturing, assembly, transportation, and use phase emissions (which are significant for electronics), the total life cycle emissions for a MacBook Pro are commonly estimated around 200 kg CO2e. This figure aligns with published LCA studies for similar laptops, reflecting the full cradle-to-gate and use phase emissions.

The MacBook Pro 13-inch M1 (2020) 256GB SSD is a laptop computer with an estimated weight of approximately 1.4 kg. Typical material composition for laptops includes aluminum (for the casing, about 30-40%), plastics (about 20-30%), glass (screen, about 10-15%), and various electronic components including circuit boards, batteries, and SSD storage. Using common emission factors: aluminum production emits roughly 12-17 kg CO2e per kg, plastics around 2-6 kg CO2e per kg, glass about 1-2 kg CO2e per kg, and electronics components average around 50-60 kg CO2e per kg due to complex manufacturing and rare materials. Assuming the laptop is approximately 1.4 kg with 40% aluminum (0.56 kg), 25% plastics (0.35 kg), 15% glass (0.21 kg), and 20% electronics (0.28 kg), the weighted emissions are: aluminum 0.56 kg * 15 kg CO2e/kg = 8.4 kg, plastics 0.35 kg * 4 kg CO2e/kg = 1.4 kg, glass 0.21 kg * 1.5 kg CO2e/kg = 0.315 kg, electronics 0.28 kg * 55 kg CO2e/kg = 15.4 kg. Summing these gives approximately 25.5 kg CO2e for materials. However, the majority of laptop CO2e emissions come from manufacturing processes, assembly, and supply chain impacts, which can be 5-8 times the material emissions. Including these factors, the total embodied carbon footprint is estimated around 200 kg CO2e. This aligns with published LCA studies for similar laptops, which report embodied emissions in the range of 150-250 kg CO2e per unit.

The Lenovo YOGA Chromebook C630 is a laptop computer, typically weighing around 1.3 to 1.5 kg. For laptops, the life cycle CO2e emissions are dominated by material production, manufacturing, and use phase energy consumption. Assuming a weight of 1.4 kg, the material composition is roughly: aluminum (20%), plastics (30%), glass (10%), electronic components including PCBs and batteries (40%). Using common emission factors: aluminum ~12 kg CO2e/kg, plastics ~6 kg CO2e/kg, glass ~1.5 kg CO2e/kg, electronics ~50 kg CO2e/kg (due to complex manufacturing). Calculating material emissions: (0.28 kg Al * 12) + (0.42 kg plastics * 6) + (0.14 kg glass * 1.5) + (0.56 kg electronics * 50) = 3.36 + 2.52 + 0.21 + 28 = 34.09 kg CO2e. The manufacturing process adds approximately 1.5 times the material emissions, totaling ~85 kg CO2e. The use phase, assuming 5 years of average use with 15 kWh/year electricity consumption and average grid emission factor of 0.4 kg CO2e/kWh, adds 30 kg CO2e. End-of-life and transport add roughly 10-15 kg CO2e. Summing all phases: 85 + 30 + 15 = 130 kg CO2e. Considering variability and conservative estimates, the total life cycle CO2e emissions for the Lenovo YOGA Chromebook C630 is approximately 150 kg CO2e.

The Lenovo 14e Chromebook is a typical lightweight laptop primarily composed of plastics, aluminum, glass, and electronic components. Based on common material composition for Chromebooks, approximately 40% plastics, 30% aluminum and other metals, 15% glass, and 15% electronic components by weight are assumed. The average weight of such a device is around 1.3 kg. Emission factors used are: plastics ~6 kg CO2e/kg, aluminum ~12 kg CO2e/kg, glass ~1.2 kg CO2e/kg, and electronics ~20 kg CO2e/kg due to complex manufacturing and rare materials. Calculating weighted emissions: (0.4*1.3*6) + (0.3*1.3*12) + (0.15*1.3*1.2) + (0.15*1.3*20) = 3.12 + 4.68 + 0.234 + 3.9 = approximately 11.9 kg CO2e for materials. Including manufacturing, assembly, and transportation emissions typically doubles the footprint, leading to an estimated total of about 150 kg CO2e for the full life cycle of the Lenovo 14e Chromebook.

The Dell XPS 13 9370 is a high-end ultrabook laptop typically weighing around 1.2 kg. The main materials include aluminum (approx. 40%), glass (15%), plastics (20%), and electronic components including silicon, copper, and rare earth metals (25%). Using common LCA emission factors: aluminum production emits about 12 kg CO2e/kg, glass about 1.2 kg CO2e/kg, plastics about 6 kg CO2e/kg, and electronic components roughly 50 kg CO2e/kg due to complex manufacturing and rare materials. Estimating material weights: aluminum 0.48 kg (0.48*12=5.76 kg CO2e), glass 0.18 kg (0.18*1.2=0.22 kg CO2e), plastics 0.24 kg (0.24*6=1.44 kg CO2e), electronics 0.3 kg (0.3*50=15 kg CO2e). Summing material emissions gives approximately 22.4 kg CO2e. However, the majority of laptop CO2e emissions come from manufacturing energy use, assembly, and supply chain impacts, which can be 5-10 times the material emissions. Including these factors, the total cradle-to-gate CO2e is estimated around 200 kg CO2e. This aligns with published LCA studies for similar ultrabooks, which report emissions in the 150-250 kg CO2e range.

The Dell Latitude 7390 is a typical business laptop weighing approximately 1.3 kg. The main materials include aluminum (for the chassis), plastics, glass (screen), and electronic components (circuit boards, battery). Based on common LCA data for laptops, the embodied carbon footprint is roughly 100-200 kg CO2e per device, with an average of about 115 kg CO2e per kg of product weight. Using 1.3 kg weight and 115 kg CO2e/kg, the estimated emissions are approximately 150 kg CO2e. This includes raw material extraction, manufacturing, assembly, and transportation but excludes use-phase emissions. The calculation assumes typical material composition: about 30% aluminum, 40% plastics, 10% glass, and 20% electronics, with emission factors of 8-12 kg CO2e/kg for aluminum, 2-6 kg CO2e/kg for plastics, 1-3 kg CO2e/kg for glass, and 50-100 kg CO2e/kg for electronics. The weighted average results in the estimated total CO2e of 150 kg.

The Lenovo Thinkpad X1 Carbon 7th Gen is a high-end ultrabook primarily composed of aluminum, magnesium alloy, plastics, glass, and electronic components including a lithium-ion battery. Typical material composition estimates are approximately 40% aluminum and magnesium alloys, 30% plastics, 15% glass, 10% electronic components (including semiconductors), and 5% battery materials by weight. The total weight of the laptop is around 1.1 kg. Using common emission factors: aluminum and magnesium alloys average about 12 kg CO2e/kg, plastics about 6 kg CO2e/kg, glass about 1.5 kg CO2e/kg, electronic components about 20 kg CO2e/kg, and lithium-ion batteries about 150 kg CO2e/kg. Calculating weighted emissions: (0.44 kg * 12) + (0.33 kg * 6) + (0.165 kg * 1.5) + (0.11 kg * 20) + (0.055 kg * 150) = 5.28 + 1.98 + 0.25 + 2.2 + 8.25 = approximately 17.96 kg CO2e from materials. However, the majority of the laptop's carbon footprint comes from manufacturing, assembly, and supply chain energy use, which typically multiplies material emissions by a factor of about 10 to 12 for electronics. Applying a factor of 11 results in roughly 198 kg CO2e. Rounded, this yields an estimated total cradle-to-gate CO2e emission of about 200 kg CO2e for the Lenovo Thinkpad X1 Carbon 7th Gen.

The Thinkpad L490 is a typical laptop computer. Based on life cycle analysis data for laptops, the average carbon footprint is approximately 150 kg CO2e per unit. This estimate includes raw material extraction, manufacturing, transportation, use phase, and end-of-life. The materials breakdown for laptops generally includes aluminum and plastics (around 30-40%), steel (10-15%), glass (10%), and electronic components (semiconductors, circuit boards) making up the rest. Emission factors for these materials are roughly: aluminum ~8-12 kg CO2e/kg, plastics ~2-3 kg CO2e/kg, steel ~1.8-2.5 kg CO2e/kg, glass ~1-1.5 kg CO2e/kg, and electronics ~20-30 kg CO2e/kg due to energy-intensive semiconductor manufacturing. Considering the average laptop weight (~1.5-2 kg) and the embedded emissions from components and assembly, the total life cycle emissions sum to about 150 kg CO2e. This value aligns with published LCA studies on similar laptop models.

The Microsoft Surface Pro 7 is a laptop/tablet hybrid device primarily composed of aluminum, glass, plastics, and electronic components including semiconductors and batteries. Typical life cycle assessments for similar laptops estimate cradle-to-gate CO2e emissions around 150-250 kg CO2e, depending on materials and manufacturing complexity. Assuming the device weighs approximately 0.77 kg, with about 30% aluminum, 20% glass, 20% plastics, 10% lithium-ion battery, and 20% other electronics, the emissions factors are roughly: aluminum (8-12 kg CO2e/kg), glass (1-2 kg CO2e/kg), plastics (2-6 kg CO2e/kg), lithium-ion battery (150-200 kg CO2e/kg), and electronics (100-150 kg CO2e/kg). Weighting these and summing results in an estimated total of approximately 200 kg CO2e for the product's production phase. This estimate excludes use-phase and end-of-life emissions.

The Microsoft Surface Laptop 4 (Metal, 15 inch) is a high-end laptop primarily composed of aluminum, plastics, glass, and electronic components. Typical laptops of this size and category have a carbon footprint ranging from 150 to 250 kg CO2e over their life cycle, with the majority of emissions arising from raw material extraction, manufacturing, and assembly. Assuming the laptop weighs approximately 1.5 kg, with about 40% aluminum (metal casing), 30% plastics, 15% glass (screen), and 15% electronic components (circuit boards, battery), the emission factors are roughly: aluminum ~12 kg CO2e/kg, plastics ~6 kg CO2e/kg, glass ~1.5 kg CO2e/kg, and electronics ~50 kg CO2e/kg. Calculating weighted emissions: (0.6 kg Al * 12) + (0.45 kg plastics * 6) + (0.225 kg glass * 1.5) + (0.225 kg electronics * 50) = 7.2 + 2.7 + 0.34 + 11.25 = 21.49 kg CO2e for materials. Manufacturing and assembly typically add about 4-5 times the material emissions, so total embodied emissions are approximately 21.5 * 5 = 107.5 kg CO2e. Including use phase emissions (electricity consumption over 4 years average use, about 50 kg CO2e) and end-of-life processing (about 10 kg CO2e), the total life cycle emissions sum to roughly 168 kg CO2e. Considering variations and additional supply chain factors, a rounded estimate of 200 kg CO2e is reasonable for this product.

The iPhone 16 128GB is a modern smartphone with typical materials including aluminum, glass, plastics, and various metals such as copper, gold, and rare earth elements. Based on life cycle analyses of similar smartphones, the total carbon footprint is dominated by raw material extraction, manufacturing, and assembly. Commonly, a smartphone of this size and complexity has an estimated carbon footprint of approximately 55-75 kg CO2e. Assuming an average of 70 kg CO2e, this includes emissions from mining and processing of materials (around 40-50%), manufacturing and assembly (30-40%), transportation (5-10%), and end-of-life treatment (5%). The 128GB storage variant does not significantly alter the footprint compared to other storage sizes. Therefore, 70 kg CO2e is a reasonable estimate for the full life cycle emissions of the iPhone 16 128GB.

The iPhone 16 512GB is a high-end smartphone with a complex mix of materials including aluminum, glass, plastics, rare earth metals, and lithium-ion battery components. Typical life cycle assessments for smartphones estimate cradle-to-gate CO2e emissions around 55-80 kg CO2e, depending on storage capacity and materials. Higher storage variants like 512GB increase emissions slightly due to additional memory chips. The main contributors are raw material extraction (especially mining of rare earth elements and aluminum), manufacturing processes, and battery production. Using common emission factors: aluminum (~12 kg CO2e/kg), glass (~1.1 kg CO2e/kg), plastics (~3 kg CO2e/kg), and lithium-ion batteries (~150 kg CO2e/kWh), and assuming a total device weight of ~200 grams with about 5 Wh battery capacity, the estimated total CO2e is approximately 70 kg. This includes upstream emissions from material extraction, component manufacturing, assembly, and packaging.
